fields.label_text:
Silver Gallery:
The inscription on this reliquary 'ECE LINVIN CRVCIS' (BEHOLD THE WOOD OF THE CROSS), suggests it once held a fragment of the cross on which Christ was crucified. Since early Christianity particles of the cross from the Basilica of the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem were considered as the most precious relics in the Catholic Church.

Reliquary of the True Cross

The bones and possessions associated with Christ and the saints are known as relics. In the Middle Ages and later they were believed to have miraculous powers and were greatly venerated. 

The relics were kept in special containers, called reliquaries, whose costly materials and beautiful workmanship reflected the importance of their contents. The relics themselves are occasionally visible, set beneath crystal windows and wrapped in a parchment tag with the name of the saint. Cathedrals and major churches accumulated reliquaries and displayed them on or near the high altar on major holy days.

This reliquary is inscribed in Latin ‘Behold the wood of the Cross’, which suggests that it held a fragment of the True Cross, the actual cross on which Christ was crucified. Catholics believed that the Empress Helena had found the True Cross in Jerusalem in the early 4th century. The fragments, which were subsequently distributed throughout Christendom, became the most precious relics in the Catholic church and often housed in double-armed crosses like this. 

Spain, about 1500
Silver gilt
Museum no. M.388-1956. Hildburgh Bequest

fields.name: Holy Relics
fields.venue: Sacred Silver and Stained Glass Galleries, the Victoria and Albert Museum

fields.physical_description: Cross of square section, hollowed to form a container for reliquary, front engraved with foliage and inscription, applied figure of Christ, back has 2 roundels with inscription.
fields.dimensions: Height: 18.60 cm, Length: 3.00 cm, Width: 8.80 cm

fields.public_access_description: The Latin inscription on this reliquary 'ECE LINVIN CRVCIS' (Behold the wood of the Cross), suggests it was made to hold a fragment of the cross on which Christ was crucified. Since the early years of Christianity, pieces of the cross from the Basilica of the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem were considered the most precious relics in the Catholic Church.

fields.history_note:
Acquisition RF: 55/4478A
Dr WL Hildburgh FSA Bequest


Bought by Hildburgh from Von Stumm Collection on Oct. 4, 1932. lot 365. Originally associated with M.344.1956, socket and knop. Lot accessioned separately.
fields.historical_context_note:
HOLY RELICS

The bones, clothing or possessions associated with Christ and the saints were known as relics.  In the Middle Ages and later they were credited with miraculous powers and much venerated. They were kept in secure containers called reliquaries, whose costly materials and beautiful workmanship reflected the importance of their contents. The relics themselves are occasionally visible, set beneath crystal windows and sometimes wrapped in a parchment tag inscribed with the name of the saint. 

Reliquaries were made in many forms. Some are modelled in the shape of the relic itself but most are box-shaped or of architectural form. The costliest are of gold and silver, embellished with precious stones, though many are of gilded and enamelled copper, decorated with scenes from the life of the saint. Cathedrals and major churches accumulated large collections of reliquaries, which were formally displayed near the high altar on major feast-days.  Most of those in museum collections no longer contain their relics.
